title: Cardiovascular system examination in children
text: This post outlines the steps in the undergraduate examination of the Cardiovascular System.

title: Cardiovascular system examination in children
text:
Courtesy and permission
The following are requisite steps in this examination. Remember to always ask for permission before undergoing any examination. Be courteous with minimal discomfort to the patient and guardian.

title: Cardiovascular system examination in children
text:
General Examination

Respiratory distress
Nutrition (Generally)
Swelling or Oedema
Dysmorphic features
Presence of medical devices e.g. Nasal prongs

title: Cardiovascular system examination in children
text:
General Examination - CVS

Hand, Arm & Leg

Pallor
Peripheral cyanosis
Capillary refill
Clubbing
Warmth
Pulse

Rate
Volume
Character
Radio-Radial & Radio-Femoral delay
Collapsing/Bounding

Blood pressure



Head & Neck

Pallor
Central cyanosis
Jaundice
Facial oedema
Neck pulsations
JVP (Older children)



Precordium

Inspection

Visible pulsations
chest wall deformities
Scars and scarifications
Chest shape



Palpation

Thrill
Apex beat location
Heave
Heart sounds



Auscultation

Heart sounds - S1, S2
Additional heart sounds - S3, S4
Murmur

Area loudest
Systolic or diastolic
Radiation
Grade

title: Cardiovascular system examination in children
text:
Others

Hepatomegaly
Edema extent - Pedal, sacral, facial
Auscultation of lung bases

title: Cardiovascular system examination in children
text:
Murmurs




Table 1: Heart diseases and their murmur charateristics










Murmur
Location

Pansystolic
LLSB
VSD, Tricuspid regurgitation


Pansystolic

Ejection systolic
ULSB
ASD, Pulmonary stenosis, Tetralogy of Fallot, Coarctation of the aorta


Continuous
2nd left ICS
Patent Dutus Arteriosus

title: Research Projects
text:
PINGS-2
The PINGS-2 (Phone-Based Intervention under Nurse Guidance after Stroke) is a multicenter randomized controlled trial where routine care of patients who had a recent stroke is compared to those who have nursing support in managing their blood pressure after the stroke. Some of the publications emanating from this project are Sarfo et al. (2021)



PedEcho
This is a review of electrocardiograms done in pediatric patients in Kumasi since 2010. It seeks to bring out the common echocardiographic diagnosis and its changing patterns over the years.



SPARCo
The Sickle Pan-African Consortium (SPARCO-II) consists of a hub in East Africa (Tanzania) and collaborative consortium sites in West Africa (Ghana, Nigeria) and Central Africa (Cameroon, Democratic Republic of Congo) which will expand to form the Sickle Pan-African Network involving 20 sites in 15 countries. This consortium is into research involving every aspect of Sickle Cell Disease in both children and adults. Some publications arising from this study include Oppong-Mensah et al. (2023)



Pediatric Weight Estimation
This is a study done in both Kumasi and Tamale to determine the accuracy of the various pediatric weight estimation methods. In the study done at the Child Department of the Tamale Teaching Hospital, children presenting with medical emergencies were recruited. The study done at the Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital however recruited children with Sickle Cell Disease, Cardiac Pathologies, and those with chronic medical conditions attending the specialist outpatient clinic. Publications arising from these studies include Cosmos Yakubu, Ayi-bisah, and Nguah (2022) and Yakubu, Paintsil, and Nguah (2023)





References

Cosmos Yakubu, Rafiuk, Nedda Ayi-bisah, and Samuel Blay Nguah. 2022. “Accuracy of Weight Estimation in Children Using the Broselow, PAWPER XL, PAWPER XL-MAC, and Mercy Tapes.” Pediatric Emergency Care 38 (9): e1517–22. https://doi.org/10.1097/pec.0000000000002638.


Oppong-Mensah, Yaa Gyamfua, Samuel Frimpong Odoom, Isaac Nyanor, Evans Xorse Amuzu, Suraj Abubakar Yawnumah, Emmanuel Asafo-Adjei, Samuel Blay Nguah, Daniel Ansong, Alex Osei-Akoto, and Vivian Paintsil. 2023. “Hospitalizations Among Children with Sickle Cell Disease Enrolled in the Kumasi Sickle Cell Pan African Consortium (SPARCo) Database: A Cross Sectional Study.” Health Science Reports 6 (9). https://doi.org/10.1002/hsr2.1534.


Sarfo, Fred Stephen, Albert Akpalu, Ansumana Bockarie, Lambert Appiah, Samuel Blay Nguah, Nana Kwame Ayisi-Boateng, Sheila Adamu, et al. 2021. “Phone-Based Intervention Under Nurse Guidance After Stroke (PINGS II) Study: Protocol for a Phase III Randomized Clinical Trial.” Journal of Stroke and Cerebrovascular Diseases 30 (8): 105888. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jstrokecerebrovasdis.2021.105888.


Yakubu, Rafiuk Cosmos, Vivian Paintsil, and Samuel Blay Nguah. 2023. “Weight Estimation in Two Groups of Ghanaian Children with Chronic Diseases Using Broselow, Mercy, PAWPER XL and PAWPER XL-MAC Tapes.” African Journal of Emergency Medicine 13 (2): 109–13. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.afjem.2023.04.003.

title: Data Description
text: This post describes the data set to be used in the workshop.

title: Data Description
text:
ANCData
Description
This dataset can be downloaded from here. It contains records of high-risk pregnant women under a trial on new and old methods of antenatal care in two clinics. The outcome was perinatal mortality. There are 755 observations with the following 3 variables.

death: A categorical variable indicating if death occurred in the infant.
anc: Indicates which type of ANC method was used.
clinic: Indicates which clinic the patient was seen at.

title: Data Description
text:
blood
Description
This dataset can be downloaded from here. It contains records of a cross-sectional study of the blood results of 50 children. It has the following 7 variables.

stno: The study ID.
age: Age in completed months of the study participants.
wgt: Weight in kilogram
hgt: Height in cms
hb: Blood hemoglobin concentration in g/dL
wbc: White blood cell count
hct: Blood hematocrit in %

title: Data Description
text:
titanic
Description
This dataset can be downloaded from here. It contains records of the fateful journey by the Titanic cruise ship. It has the following 5 variables.

class: The class in which the person was.
age: Age in completed years.
sex: Sex
survived: Whether the person survived the sinking of the ship
died: Whether the person died as a result of the accident

title: Data Description
text:
schisto
Description
This dataset can be downloaded from here. It was obtained from 367 pupils in a community in Ghana. The cross-sectional study was to determine the effect of urinary schistosomiasis on the nutritional status as well as blood indices of school children. It has the following 15 variables.

Serial0: The study ID.
Q3Age: Age in completed years.
Q4Sex: The sex of the pupil.
Q35weight: Weight in kilogram
Q36Height: Height in cms
Q6Religion: Religious affiliation
Educationalstatus: Level of education
Q15PipeBorne: Does the pupil use bipe-borne water at home? 0 = No, 1 = Yes
Q15Well: Does the pupil use well water at home? 0 = No, 1 = Yes
Q15River: Does the pupil use river water at home? 0 = No, 1 = Yes
HB: Blood hemoglobin concentration in g/dL
SH: Shistosomiasis ova in the urine. Nil, +, ++, and +++
HCT: Blood hematocrit in %
MCV: Mean Corpuscular Volume
MCH: Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin

title: Data Description
text:
NewDrug
Description
This dataset can be downloaded from here. It was obtained in a randomized controlled trial of a new drug against a control drug. It measured the mean blood pressure of study participants before and after the drugs were administered. It has the following 6 variables.

id: Study ID
treat: Treatment given
age: Age in completed years.
sex: Gender of participant
bp1: Mean arterial BP before treatment
bp2: Mean arterial BP after treatment

title: Data Description
text:
Outbreak
Description
This data can be downloaded from here. It contains information from an outbreak investigation concerning food poisoning on a sportsday in Thailand 1990.
Dichotomous variables for exposures and symptoms were coded as 0 = No, 1 = yes and 9 = Missing.
It contains the following variables

id: Study ID
sex: Sex of study person. 0 = Female, 1 = Male.
age: Age of participant. 99 = Missing
exptime: Character version of time of exposure
beefcurry: Whether the subject ate beef curry
saltegg: Whether the subject ate salted eggs
eclair: Pieces of eclair eaten by participants. 80 = “ate but could not remember how much”, 90 = totally missing information
water: Whether the subject drunk water
onset: Character version of time of onset
nausea: Whether the subject had nausea
vomiting: Whether the subject had vomiting
abdpain: Whether the subject had abdominal pain
diarrhea: Whether the subject had diarrhea

title: Practical 3: Hypothesis testing
text: This is the third practical lesson where we learn how about hypothesis testing

title: Practical 3: Hypothesis testing
text:
Objectives

Numeric variables

One sample

Independent T-test
Wilcoxon Rank Sum test

Two sample

Independent sample T-test
Mann-Whitney U test

Paired test

Paired sample T-test
Wilcoxon Rank Sum test


Categorical variables

One sample

Binomial test
Chi-square goodness of fit test

Two sample

Independent X-squared association
Odds, Risk, Difference in proportion

title: Practical 1: Data preparation
text: This is the first practical lesson where we learn how to prepare data before analysis.

title: Practical 1: Data preparation
text:
Objectives

Read data from differing formats
Editing variable names
Labelling variables
Editing value labels
Setting variable types
Arrange variable levels appropriately
Deriving new variables
Transforming variables

title: Practical 1: Data preparation
text:
Practical
To do this we will begin with the schisto data. Please download and save it on your computer if you have not done so already.

Create a folder on your computer
Save the data in the folder.
Import the data into Jamovi
Make sure all variable types reflect the type of variable collected
Appropriately labels all categorical or ordinal variables
Edit the names of the variables to the appropriate names
Create a variable BMI from the weight and height
Create an ordinal variable from the HB as: Severe = <8g/dl, Moderate = 8g/dl to <10g/dl and Mlld = 10g/dl to <12g/dl and >=12g/dl = Normal
Save the data as schisto.omv

title: Practical 1: Data preparation
text:
To do

Download the blood data
Read it into Jamovi
Make sure all variable types reflect the type of variable collected
Appropriately labels all categorical or ordinal variables
Edit the names of the variables to the appropriate names
Create a variable BMI from the weight and height
Create an ordinal variable from the HB as: Severe = <8g/dl, Moderate = 8g/dl to <10g/dl and Mlld = 10g/dl to <12g/dl and >=12g/dl = Normal
Save data as blood.omv

title: Practical 6: Sample size determination
text:
In this part we learn how to determine sample sizes for different study methodologies.

Form 5 groups
Let’s have 10 minutes to discuss each other project and the determinants of your sample size
We use the website https://sample-size.net/ for the sample size determination
We meet afterward to determine the sample sizes for different designs

title: Practical 2: Exploratory data analysis
text: This is the second practical lesson where we learn how to perform exploratory data analysis

title: Practical 2: Exploratory data analysis
text:
Objectives

Explore the data
Summaries

Tabulation
Measures of central tendency, dispersion, distribution

Graphics

Categorical

Barchart

Numeric

Histogram, density plot, boxplot, QQplot, violin plot,

Categorical vs Categorical

Barplot

Numeric vs numeric
Categorical vs Numeric

title: Dr Samuel Blay Nguah
text:
Dr. Samuel Blay Nguah is a pediatrician and medical statistician based in Kumasi, the second-largest city in Ghana. He is a Senior Lecturer in the Department of Child Health of the School of Medicine and Dentistry, Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology.
He has been a practicing consultant pediatrician at the Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital since 2010 and as a doctor since 2000. He has a special interest in Paediatric Cardiology, caring for children with congenital and acquired heart diseases since 2007.
As a medical statistician, he has actively participated in many surveys and research, with well over 50 publications in peer-reviewed medical journals. He is an ardent user of the R software for data analysis and visualization. He frequently gives talks to resident doctors in training on topics, including research methods and biostatistics.
His hobbies include reading, swimming, and gardening.

title: Dr Samuel Blay Nguah
text:
Dr. Samuel Blay Nguah is a pediatrician and medical statistician based in Kumasi, the second-largest city in Ghana. He is a Senior Lecturer in the Department of Child Health of the School of Medicine and Dentistry, Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology.
He has been a practicing consultant pediatrician at the Komfo Anokye Teaching Hospital since 2010 and as a doctor since 2000. He has a special interest in Paediatric Cardiology, caring for children with congenital and acquired heart diseases since 2007.
As a medical statistician, he has actively participated in many surveys and research, with well over 50 publications in peer-reviewed medical journals. He is an ardent user of the R software for data analysis and visualization. He frequently gives talks to resident doctors in training on topics, including research methods and biostatistics.
His hobbies include reading, swimming, and gardening.
